Award.AwardTitle: Finitely presented groups at The City College of New York, Spring 2009 conference
Award.AbstractNarration: How can you tell whether a knot is really knotted or <br/>whether it is possible to find a formula for the <br/>solutions of certain equations or how to make sense<br/>of the nature of the elementary particles of physics <br/>or why there are only 17 really different wall paper <br/>patterns? These and many other such questions depend <br/>on an algebraic structure called a group. Groups arise <br/>in many parts of mathematics and in science. They provide, <br/>in particular, the means to understand and exploit<br/>symmetry. This makes it possible for them to help<br/>in our understanding of the nature of the space we live <br/>in, the structure of crystals and various molecules <br/>and in the design of new cryptographic protocols. Indeed <br/>the security of information transmitted electronically <br/>over the internet depends crucially on a particular kind <br/>of group called a finite group. This group provides a way<br/>to encode messages using the product of two very large prime<br/>numbers. The encoding is the easy part of the process.<br/>The hard part is the decoding and this is where group theory<br/>is used. The present proposal deals with the current state of<br/>knowledge of certain groups, called finitely presented groups.<br/>These finitely presented groups hold in many instances the keys<br/>to solving important problems in mathematics and science<br/>and the primary objective of this conference is for a number<br/>of very prominent mathematicians to map out future directions <br/>of study.<br/>

Institution.Name: CUNY City College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK
